Table of Contents

NAME

rsencode - Reed-Solomon coding

SYNOPSIS

rsencode [-k k] [-n n] infile outfile

OPTIONS

-k k
Integer. The number of message symbols per coded block. Default = 10.
-n n
Integer. The total number of symbols per coded block. Default = 15.

DESCRIPTION

rsencode implements Reed-Solomon forward-error-correction (FEC) coding of a file. infile is the filename of the file to be FEC protected; outfile is the resulting FEC-protected file. It is assumed that symbols stored in infile are single-character bytes; i.e., it is a text file.

Reed-Solomon coding is a (n, k) FEC code; that is, n - k FEC symbols are concatenated to k message symbols to produce an n-symbol block. The n - k FEC symbols are redundant information that aids in the recovery of the k message symbols should some of these symbols be lost or corrupted during transmission of the coded file. In particular, Reed-Solomon coding has the property that if up to n - k symbols out of the n symbols in the coded block are lost, the original k message symbols can be recovered exactly.

rsencode reads k symbols (i.e., single-byte characters) from infile, calculates the corresponding n - k FEC symbols for these k message symbols, and then writes the corresponding length-n coded block to outfile. When the end of file of infile is encountered, zeros are added as needed to fill out the last block to k symbols before calculating the FEC symbols. Thus the length of outfile is ceil(N/k)*n, where N is the length of infile.

NOTES

Reed-Solomon codes were introduced in 1960 by Reed and Solomon. The implementation found in QccPack follows that by Rizzo.

SEE ALSO

QccECCReedSolomonEncode(3) , QccECCReedSolomonDecode(3) , QccPackECC(3) , QccPack(3)

I. S. Reed and G. Solomon, "Polynomial Codes Over Certain Finite Fields," J. Soc. Ind. Appl. Math., vol. 8, pp. 300-304, 1960.

L. Rizzo, "Effective Erasure Codes for Reliable Computer Communication Protocols," ACM Computer Communication Review, vol. 27, no. 2, pp. 24-36, April 1997.
